.hack.description: .hack//LINK includes a bonus pre-order DVD featuring a crossover between Haseo and Asbel from Tales of Graces, and Haseo also gets an Asbel costume in the game while Asbel gets a DLC costume of Haseo's Xth Form in Tales of Graces ƒ; a Haseo costume with his actual techniques is also featured in Tales of Phantasia: Narikiri Dungeon X. Haseo and Atoli from .hack appear in Tales of the Rays.

Commander Video from Bit.Trip appears as a playable character in 1001 Spikes.

101 Dalmatians.description: Lady, Tramp, Jock, Peg and Bull in appear in 101 Dalmations. Jock also appears in 101 Dalmations 2:Patch's Londan Adventure and 101 Dalmations: The Series episode Home Is Where The Bark Is.
The dogs can be seen watching The Aristocats in the live action 101 Dalmations movie.

1080\u00b0.description: In 1080° Avalanche there are some references to the Mario series.

10 Things I Hate About You.description: Rambo is mentioned in 10 Things I Hate About You.

Castle Rock from The Stand appears in 11/22/63.

194X.description: Mobichan from Side Arms appears as an item and in the credits of 1943: The Battle of Midway and as an item in 1944: The Loop Master, while "1942" is one of the default names in the hi-score screen in Side Arms.
The dragonfly and bamboo sprout from SonSon appear as items in several games of the 194X series.

Cammy is featured in artworks for 1942: Joint Strike, while planes from 1942 are selectable in Street Fighter × All Capcom. 2019: World President Challenges an STG is a format crossover between both series.
Chapter 21 of High Score Girl has a cameo of 1942, while the website intro of 2019: World President Challenges an STG features a mini-manga animation of High Score Girl.

2064: Read Only Memories.description: Characters from 2064: Read Only Memories make cameo appearances in VA-11 Hall-A and vice versa.

2 Broke Girls.description: When Harry Met Sally... is mentioned in the Two Broke Girls episode: "And The Broken Hearts".
Caroline Channing says 'even snakes have been on a plane' in the Two Broke Girls episode "And Just Plane Magic"; Snakes On A Plane is mentioned in the Two Broke Girls episode "And The Rom-Commie".
Pretty Woman is mentioned in the Two Broke Girls episode "And The Fat Cat".
Patrick Bateman is mentioned in the 2 Broke Girls episode: "And a Loan for Christmas".

Risky Business is mentioned in the Two Broke Girls episode "And The Turtle Sense".

30 Days of Night.description: The X-Files 30 Days of Night comic is a crossover between the two series
In Infestation 2: 30 Days of Night it is shown that the world of 30 Days of Night are attacked by the same Great Old Ones

30 Rock.description: Law And Order is mentioned in the 30 Rock episode "Pilot".
Characters use the word 'jedi' in the 30 Rock episode "Pilot".
Pete Hornberger pretends to be Elmo in the 30 Rock episode "Black Tie".
Jerry Maguire is mentioned in the 30 Rock episode "C Word".
Seinfeld is featured in the 30 Rock episode "Seinfeldvision".
In the 30 Rock episode "The One with the Cast of Night Court", cast members from Night Court are reunited to stage a wedding between two characters from Night Court.

When Harry Met Sally... is mentioned in the 30 Rock episode: "Let's Stay Together".
Abby Flynn gets a note reading 'I thought this box would be the perfect size for your head. PS: I was electrocuted again while watching Seven' in the 30 Rock episode "TGS Hates Women".
Sixth Sense is mentioned in the 30 Rock episode "Standards And Practices".
ParaNorman is mentioned in the 30 Rock episode: "The Beginning Of The End".
The 30 Rock episode "Stride of Pride" features many references to Pokémon.

3D Dot Game Heroes.description: 3D Dot Game Heroes features an unlockable "Spelunker Mode" where the player controls the Spelunker; there also are two loading screens based on Spelunker.
3D Dot Game Heroes features a character from Armored Core 4, downloadable in the Japanese version, while available from the start in international versions.
3D Dot Game Heroes features characters from the Tenchu series, downloadable in the Japanese version, while available from the start in international versions.

3D Mania.description: Elvira appears in the movie Encounter in the Thrid Dimension.

3 Ninjas.description: In a scene of 3 Ninjas, one of the main characters is seen playing Super Mario Bros. 3, while a balloon version of Mario can be seen in 3 Ninjas Kick Back.

A human version of Street Fighter II appears in 404 GAME RE:SET.
A human version of Puyo Puyo appears in 404 GAME RE:SET.

The film Alien VS. Predator is mentioned in the 6teen episode Wrestlemania.

Clunk from Awesomenauts appears as a playable character in Tricky Towers as part of the "Indie Friends Pack".
Octodad appears as a playable character in Tricky Towers as part of the "Indie Friends Pack".
Candy Man from Lethal League appears as a playable character in Tricky Towers as part of the "Indie Friends Pack".
The Last of the Order from TowerFall appears as a playable character in Tricky Towers as part of the "Indie Friends Pack".

A.N.T. Farm.description: C-3PO, R2-D2 and a Stormtrooper appear in the A.N.T. Farm episode scavANTger.
Mr. Hashimoto from The Suite Life on Deck appears in the A.N.T. Farm episodes independANTs, product misplacemANT and FinANTial crisis.

ADK World.description: World Heroes characters are featured in the main world and in various minigames.
Kisarah Westfield from Aggressors of Dark Kombat appears in the main world and is featured in some minigames.
Rayar Dragon and Ryu Eagle from Ninja Commando appear in some minigames.

AFK Arena.description: Ukyo and Nakoruru from Samurai Shodown appear as characters in AFK Arena.
Ezio from Assassin's Creed appears as a character in AFK Arena.
Ainz and Albedo from Overlord appear as characters in AFK Arena.

AFK Arena.description: Rimuru and Shuna appears as characters in AFK Arena.

AFTERLOST.description: Costumes based on Angry Birds can be obtained in AFTERLOST as part of a special collaboration.
Psycho-Pass characters appear in AFTERLOST for a collaboration event.

AI: The Somnium Files.description: Shenron from Dragon Ball is mentioned in AI: The Somnium Files.
Sadako from The Ring is mentioned in AI: The Somnium Files.
Yuri Katsuki from Yuri on Ice is mentioned in AI: The Somnium Files.

In AI: The Somnium Files, Date jokingly tells a witness "I'm psychic", a possible reference to Sayaka making the same joke in Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc. In the same game, Iris mentions feeling like a black and white bear is going to punish her, referencing Monokuma from Danganronpa. Additionally, Iris's Somnium in AI: The Somnium Files: nirvanA Initiative has Monokuma and Shiren as secret Kusemon.

A poster for Zero Escape can be found in AI: The Somnium Files. Additionally, a girl from the crew quarters from Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward can be found on a TV screen. Also, in AI: The Somnium Files nirvanA Intiative, The masks of K and Q are unlockable outfits for Aiba and Tama while Zero's is DLC.

ALF.description: Brian Tanner calls Alf "ET" in the ALF episode "ALF".
Sesame Street is mentioned in the ALF episode "ALF".
ALF sings The Jetsons opening theme song in the episode "Pennsylvania 6-5000".
ALF plays the Atari 2600 version of Space Invaders in the episode "Border Song".
The Bob Newhart Show is mentioned in "Going Out of My Head Over You" with Bill Daly and Jack Riley from The Bob Newhart Show appearing as different characters.
ALF dreams he meets the characters from Gilligan's Island.
Exclusive to the Brazilian dub, ALF, Paul and Lynn are watching a random episode of ThunderCats in the episode "I'm Your Puppet".
There’s a minor reference to The Godfather in the season 3 episode “Hide Away” of ALF.
ALF re-enacts scenes from The Dick Van Dyke Show in the ALF episode "Having my Baby".

ALIEN XENOBLASTER.description: Annalynn is a playable character in ALIEN XENOBLASTER.
Peppino is a playable character in ALIEN XENOBLASTER.

AR Games.description: The Fishing AR game features various Mario creatures; the Star Pics AR game uses a Mario card, while the ? card is likely based on the "?" Block from the Mario series; there also are Mario references in Graffiti.
The Star Pics AR game uses a Link card, and there also are Zelda refereneces in Graffiti.
The Star Pics AR game uses a Kibry card, and there also are Kirby refereneces in Graffiti.
The Star Pics AR game uses a Samus card, and there also are Metroid refereneces in Graffiti.
The Star Pics AR game uses a Pikmin card, and there also are Pikmin refereneces in Graffiti.

A Bug's Life.description: The Pizza Planet Truck appears in A Bug's Life as well as Woody and the phrase "to infinity and beyond" during the credits; A Bug's Life merchandise appears in Toy Story 2. Flik and Heimlich appear in the outtakes of Toy Story 2. Heimlich himself appears in Toy Story 2 when Buzz chops down a bush. The Circus Bugs appear in Toy Story 4.

A Certain (Series).description: Yoshida Kazumi from the Shakugan no Shana appears in the A Certain Scientific Railgun episode, Electromaster
Index appears in the Disgaea series during the Omega Heal spell animation in Disgaea 4: A Promise Revisited.

Toaru Majutsu no Index VS Durarara!! Special Collaboration is a crossover between the two series. Additionally, A Certain Magical Index Illusion Convergence features several characters from Durarara!! as part of a special collaboration.
Toaru Majutsu no Virtual-On as well as its video game adaptation called A Certain Magical Virtual-On are a crossover between the two series.
Miyabi and Yumi from Senran Kagura appear as playable characters in Toaru Majutsu no Index MMO during collaboration events.
Sakura Shinguji from Sakura Wars appear as a playable character in Toaru Majutsu no Index MMO during a collaboration event.
Characters from BanG Dream! appear in A Certain Scientific Railgun T as part of a special collaboration.
Characters from KonoSuba appear in A Certain Magical Index: Illusion Convergence as part of a special collaboration.
Characters from Unison League and A Certain Scientific Railgun T appear in each other’s games as part of a special collaboration.
Characters from NieR appear in A Certain Magical Index Illusion Convergence as part of a special collaboration.
Characters from Is It Wrong to Try to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon? III appear in A Certain Magical Index: Illusion Convergence as part of a collaboration.

A Certain (Series).game: That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime
A Certain (Series).description: Characters from That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime appear in A Certain Magical Index: Illusion Convergence as part of a special collaboration.

A Certain (Series).game: The Irregular at Magic High School
A Certain (Series).description: A Certain Magical Index Illusion Convergence and The Irregular at Magic High School Reloaded Memory are in a joint collaboration with each other.
Characters from Overlord appear in A Certain Magical Index Illusion Convergence as part of a special collaboration.

A Clockwork Orange.description: Soundtrack album of 2001 is displayed in Clockwork Orange.

A Hat in Time.description: A Hat in Time features a Brewing Hat flair that makes it resemble Vivian's hat from Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door, as well as color palettes with the color scheme of Princess Peach and Wario. The "Virtual Kid Costume" makes Hat Kid take on the visual style of Super Mario 64, with A Hat in Time Time Rift areas inspired by Super Mario Sunshine; while The Snatcher mentions Luigi in one of his quips in the Death Wish DLC; there are several other minor references to Mario.

A Hat in Time features a color palette with the color scheme of Link from The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker named "Forest Critter", while one of Hat Kid's idle animations is based on Link's victory animation.

A Hat in Time features a color palette with the color scheme of Niko from OneShot named "Margin of Night", referencing the game's main artist and musician Nightmargin, while an official mod features Niko's clothing and The Sun as an ability.
A Hat in Time features a color palette with the color scheme of Sash Lilac from Freedom Planet named "The Freedom", while an official mod features Lilac's Headpiece and the Dragon Cyclone ability.

An outline of Raz from Psychonauts can be found on the floor of the attic in Vanessa's Manor, a bonus sticker could also be obtained in an update if you owned A Hat in Time and Psychonauts 2 on Steam, the C.A.W. Agents in A Hat in Time are inspired by the G-Men in Psychonauts and an official mod features Raz's Goggles and a PSI-Power ability.
The Seal the Deal DLC added a costume named "Hiking Shorts Costume", based on Banjo's outfit.
In the stage "The Arctic Cruise" from A Hat in Time: Seal the Deal there's a monitor displaying a game of Asteroids.
In the stage "The Arctic Cruise" from A Hat in Time: Seal the Deal there's a monitor displaying a game of Space Invaders.
In the stage "The Arctic Cruise" from A Hat in Time: Seal the Deal there's a monitor displaying a game of Pong.
A Hat in Time features two color palettes referencing the red and blue team from Team Fortress 2, named "Fortress" and "Battlements".
An official mod for A Hat in Time features Shovel Knight's helmet and shovel.
An official mod for A Hat in Time features the Drifter's Hood and Chain Rush ability.

A Million Ways to Die in the West.description: Django appears as a cameo in A Million Ways To Die In The West.
Doc Brown appears as a cameo in A Million Ways To Die In The West.

A Nightmare on Elm Street.description: In the episode "Missing Persons" of the Freddy's Nightmares TV series, two children play Super Mario Bros.
Freddy vs. Jason is a direct movie crossover between the two series.
In an ad for Halloween Horror Nights 17, Freddy Krueger from Nightmare on Elm Street appears with Leatherface from The Texas Chainsaw Massacre.

A Nightmare on Elm Street features a reference to The Evil Dead, while Evil Dead II features a reference to the Nightmare on Elm Street series; Freddy vs. Jason vs. Ash is a direct crossover between the two series.
In an ad for Halloween Horror Night , Freddy Krueger from Nightmare on Elm Street appears with Jack the Clown.

A Series of Unfortunate Events.description: The Aflac Duck appears in Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events.
A movie titled "Men in Beige" is being played at a movie theater in Episode 3 of A Series of Unfortunate Events.

A Thousand Words.description: An Austin Powers doll is shown in A Thousand Words.
An Elmo doll is shown in A Thousand Words.
A Terminator doll is shown in A Thousand Words.
An Et doll is shown in A Thousand Words.
A Spongebob doll is shown in A Thousand Words.

Abbott Elementary.description: Janine mentions Toy Story in the pilot episode of Abbott Elementary.
Micah likes Bluey in the Abbott Elementary episode "The Principal’s Office".
There is a student dressed as Thanos in the Abbott Elementary episode "Candy Zombies".
Janine has Tariq's Charmeleon plushie in the Abbott Elementary episode "Attack Ad".
Janine mentions Attack on Titan in the Abbott Elementary episode "Attack Ad".
One of Jake's students mentions One-Punch Man in the Abbott Elementary episode "Attack Ad".

Abomi Nation.description: Creatures from Bug Fables appear in Abomi Nation as part of a special collaboration.

Academy of Champions.description: Altair from Assassin's Creed makes an appearance in Academy of Champions: Football.
Jade from Beyond Good & Evil makes an appearance in Academy of Champions: Football.
The main character from the 2008 game Prince of Persia makes an appearance in Academy of Champions: Football.
Rayman makes an appearance in Academy of Champions: Football.
Sam Fisher from the Splinter Cell game series makes an appearance in Academy of Champions: Football.
Raving Rabbids make an appearance in Academy of Champions: Football.

Accel World.description: In the Accel World episode "Insurrection" the characters can be seen playing Tekken Tag Tournament 2.

Kuroyukihime from Accel World appears in Sword Art Online: Lost Song. The two franchises also crossed over in 'Versus'. The author of both series has also confirmed that Accel World takes place in the near future of Sword Art Online.

Ace Attorney.description: The English language version of Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney: Trials and Tribulations features a reference to the line "Spoony Bard" from Final Fantasy IV.

The English language version of Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney: Trials and Tribulations features a reference to Metal Gear Solid. Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney 5 - Dual Destinies features both dialogue and visual references as well.
The English language version of Apollo Justice: Ace Attorney features a reference to Doctor Who.
Professor Layton vs. Ace Attorney is a crossover between the two series.
DLC costumes based on Sengoku BASARA characters are featured in the Japanese version of Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Spirit of Justice.

Ace Combat.description: Ace Combat features images of Pac-Man on billboards, while Ace Combat: Assault Horizon Legacy + features unlockable aircraft themed after Pac-Man; Ace Combat 2, Ace Combat 5, Ace Combat 6 and Infinity also feature minor references.

Ace Combat 2 features the sister of Reiko Nagase as a selectable pilot, and she also returns in later episodes, while organizations from Ace Combat 3 appear as sponsors in Ridge Racer V and Ridge Racer 6; there also are other minor references between the two series.
The Special Flag from Rally-X appears as an item in Ace Combat Zero: The Belkan War.

Ace Combat 6, Assault Horizon, and Infinity feature aircraft paints based on THE iDOLM@STER. The third game expanded the collaboration by including emblems and nicknames based on THE iDOLM@STER characters and songs.
Camilla from Ace Combat Infinity humes the main theme of Mappy during a mission; the game also features nicknames and emblems based on the series.

Bacuras from Xevious started appearing in the Co-Op Mission "Tokyo Martial Law" from Ace Combat Infinity as part of a collaboration event, with Xevious-themed emblems being handed out at a later date; while city structures in Ace Combat 3: Electrosphere resemble the Andor Genesis from Xevious.

The Sword Art Online II anime features references to Ace Combat. Ace Combat Infinity fetures emblems and nicknames based on Sword Art Online: Hollow Realization as part of a limited collaboration event.

The "Quox Armored Battalion" from Ace Combat 6: Fires of Liberation is named after an enemy from The Tower of Druaga, while Ace Combat Infinity features emblems and nicknames based on The Tower of Druaga obtained through Speical Supply tickets.

Ace Combat Infinity features nicknames and emblems based on Galaxian, Galaga and Gaplus gained through Special Supply tickets, while music from the unrelesead Galaxian Heroes was featured in the compilation soundtrack Ace Combat Infinity & Series Music Best.
Ace Combat 6: Fires of Liberation features a building's lights in the shape of a Pooka from Dig Dug in Mission 14, while Ace Combat Infinity features emblems and nicknames based on Dig Dug.
Ace Combat Infinity features emblems based on characters from Soulcalibur Lost Swords as part of a collaboration event.

Question Blocks and Power Stars from the Mario series appear in Ace Combat: Assault Horizon Legacy +, and are used to unlock aircraft themed after Nintendo characters, including Mario, Luigi, Princess Peach and Bowser.
Ace Combat: Assault Horizon Legacy + features unlockable aircraft themed after Donkey Kong.
Ace Combat: Assault Horizon Legacy + features unlockable aircraft themed after Link from Skyward Sword and Zelda from Twilight Princess.
Ace Combat: Assault Horizon Legacy + features unlockable aircraft themed after Samus from Metroid: Other M.
Ace Combat: Assault Horizon Legacy + features unlockable aircraft themed after Fox from Star Fox 64 3D.
Ace Combat: Assault Horizon Legacy + features unlockable aircraft themed Captain Falcon from F-Zero X.
Ace Combat Infinity features emblems based on God Eater 2 Rage Burst and God Eater Resurrection as part of two limited collaboration events.

As part of a limited collaboration event in Ace Combat Infinity for the release of Godzilla-VS, Godzilla and Mechagodzilla would appear in the Tokyo Martial Law Co-Op mission, the event also handed out emblems and nicknames based on the game.
Scanning Olimar's amiibo unlocks a Pikmin-themed aircraft in Ace Combat: Assault Horizon Legacy +.
Ace Combat Infinity features an emblem based on the main character sprite from Baraduke as a Special Supply ticket reward.
Ace Combat Infinity features emblems and nicknames based on Pixels as part of a limited collaboration event.
Ace Combat Infinity features emblems and nicknames based on Doko Demo Issyo as part of a limited collaboration event.

The Red Baron and Blue Max aircrafts from Sky Kid were unlockable Special Aircrafts during a limited time tournament event in Ace Combat Infinity, there are several other minor references to the series in Ace Combat 04, 5, 6 and Infinity.
Ace Combat Infinity features emblems and nicknames based on Digimon World -next 0rder- as part of a limited collaboration event.

Ace Ventura.description: Stay Tuned is featured in Ace Ventura: Pet Detective. "You Can't Win" game show is being watched by Ace's landlord.
Ace Ventura appears in the Mask: Animated Series episode "The Aceman Cometh", while The Mask appears in the Ace Ventura: Pet Detective episode "Have Mask Will Travel".

Action Man.description: Action Man was created as a licensed version of the original G.I. Joe; an Action Man figure also appears in the Valor vs. Venom line of G.I. Joe toys.
In the United Kingdom, Rom was released as part of the Action Man toy line.

Addams Family.description: Fester meets Mario from Super Mario Bros. in the 1989 flyer, Catch the Title Wave.
Fester meets a football player from Tecmo Bowl in the 1989 flyer, Catch the Title Wave.
Fester meets Ryu from Ninja Gaiden in the 1989 flyer, Catch the Title Wave.
Ryu meets Michelangelo from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in the 1989 flyer, Catch the Title Wave.
Plushes of BabyRiki versions of Chiko, Rosa and Pandy appear among Enid's collection of stuffed animals in the Wednesday episode "If You Don’t Woe Me by Now".

Adopt Me!.description: Adopt Me! was released as a Roblox experience and the player's Roblox Avatar can be used in it.
Scooby-Doo appears as a pet in Adopt Me! as part of a special event.
Buster Moon appears in Adopt Me! as part of a special event.
A Zodiac Minion Chick from Minions: The Rise of Gru appears as a pet in Adopt Me! as part of a special event.
Gru appears as a NPC in Adopt Me! as part of a special event.
Puss in Boots appears in Adopt Me! as part of a special event.

Adventure Island.description: Sound effects from Challenger can be heard in multiple episodes of the Bugtte Honey anime.
Sound effects from Milon's Secret Castle are played in multiple episodes of Bugtte Honey.

Adventure Quiz.description: The Adventure Quiz series features characters from Forgotten Worlds.
The Adventure Quiz series features characters from Mega Man, while a Pure the Mage doll was meant to appear in Spring Man's stage in Mega Man 7.
The Adventure Quiz series features characters from Ghosts 'n Goblins.
Adventure Quiz: Capcom World features Mobi-chan from Side Arms.
The Adventure Quiz series features characters from Kamen no Ninja Hanamaru.
Capcom Quiz: Hatena? no Daibouken features characters from 1942.
The Adventure Quiz series features characters from Final Fight.
The Adventure Quiz series features characters from Strider.
Adventure Quiz: Capcom World 2 features characters from Street Fighter II. Pure from Adventure Quiz: Capcom World 2 makes a cameo as a party guest in Street Fighter Alpha 2.
Adventure Quiz: Capcom World 2 features characters from Captain Commando.
Adventure Quiz: Capcom World 2 features characters from The King of Dragons.
Adventure Quiz: Capcom World 2 features characters from Knights of the Round.
Adventure Quiz: Capcom World 2 features characters from Magic Sword: Heroic Fantasy.
Adventure Quiz: Capcom World 2 features characters from Three Wonders.

Adventure Time.description: A shadow of Batman appears in the Adventure Time episode "City of Thieves". "Holly Jolly Secrets Part II" features a reference to Batman.
Marceline wears Freddy Krueger's sweater in "It Came from the Nightosphere".
In the episode Beautopia, when Susan leaves the Fish People, she says "I'll be back" which is a quote by Arnold Schwarzenegger in the Terminator movies.

A character dressed like the Ice King from Adventure Time appears in the season 2 episode See You There from Regular Show. The Maximum Glove from the Regular Show episode Video Game Wizards appears as an item in Adventure Time: Time Tangle. Mordecai from Regular Show appears in the Adventure Time episode Ketchup. The Adventure Time/Regular Show comic is a crossover between both series.
Garfield is mentioned on a pet bowl in the Adventure Time episode High Strangeness.
UNDIRECT: Jake from Adventure Time mimics a dance from Fortnite in an official Cartoon Network video, though the video isn't part of either series.
Bloons Adventure Time TD is a crossover between the two series.

The Adventure Time episode: "Diamonds and Lemons" is a crossover with Minecraft. In the episode: "Dungeon", the music playing when the Guardian Angel appears to Finn bears uncanny resemblance to "Mice on Venus" by C418 from Minecraft. In the episode: "Return to the Nightosphere", during the first recording of the Nightosphere, a creature floats by that looks similar to a Ghast from Minecraft. Minecraft Bedrock Edition features an Adventure Time mash-up pack.
Cheers is mentioned several times throughout Fionna and Cake.

Adventures of Lolo.description: Adventures of Lolo is a spin off of Eggerland.

Adventures of Pip.description: Shovel Knight makes a cameo in an updated version of Adventures of Pip.

Aegis Defenders.description: Shovel Knight makes an appearance in Aegis Defenders.
Derpl Zork makes an appearance in Aegis Defenders.

Aero the Acro-Bat.description: Zero the Kamikaze Squirrel is a spinoff of Aero the Acro-Bat.

Aflac.description: The Aflac duck appears with Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner in an Aflac commercial.
The Aflac Duck appears with characters from Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer in an Aflac commercial.
The Aflac Duck appears with characters from Up in an Aflac commercial.
The Aflac Duck appears with characters from Toy Story in an Aflac commercial.
An Aflac ad inserted an animated Aflac Duck into the opening credits of the DuckTales reboot.
An Aflac ad inserted an animated Aflac Duck into the opening credits of Scoob!.
The Aflac Duck appears alongside Puss in Boots in an Aflac commercial.

After Burner.description: Opa-Opa appears in the Japanese instruction manual of After Burner for Master System.

Afterparty.description: Jessica Rabbit is mentioned in Afterparty.
Indiana Jones is mentioned in Afterparty.

Agent Carter.description: Agent Carter is a spin-off of Captain America: The First Avenger.

Aggressors of Dark Kombat.description: Kotaro Fuuma from World Heroes is selectable in Aggressors of Dark Kombat.

AirMech.description: Armillo from Armillo is a pet in AirMech.
The Creeper from Minecraft is an Infantry unit in AirMech.
Characters from Penny Arcade are pilots in AirMech.
The Sentry Turret from Portal is a Turret unit in AirMech.

Air Bud.description: Buddies is a spin-off of the Air Bud series.

Airforce Delta.description: The Vic Viper from Gradius is playable in Airforce Delta Storm and Airforce Delta Strike.
The MANBOU-J from Space Manbow is playable in Airforce Delta Storm and Airforce Delta Strike.
The TwinBee is playable in Airforce Delta Storm and Airforce Delta Strike.
Penta from Antarctic Adventure is playable in Airforce Delta Strike.
The Black Shooter from Quarth is playable in Airforce Delta Strike.
The FLINT-ROCK from Xexex is playable in Airforce Delta Strike.

Airplane!.description: The Enterprise from Star Trek appears in a scene in Airplane II: The Sequel.

Akame ga Kill!.description: In chapter 4 of the Akame ga Kill! manga, Mine threatens Tatsumi to banish him to another manga. Higurashi no Naku Koro Ni: Matsuribayashi-hen and Umineko no Naku Koro Ni are two of the choices.
In chapter 4 of the Akame ga Kill! manga, Mine threatens Tatsumi to banish him to another manga. Natsu no Arashi! is one of the choices.

Akimbot.description: In one of the levels in Akimbot, there is a neon sign in the shape of Jack's face with a text that reads "Hi Jack".

Aladdin (Disney).description: Genie gains Bonkers' head in the Aladdin series episode "Snowman is an Island.
Genie transforms into Pumba from Lion King in Aladdin 3 and Aladdin characters appear in Lion King 1½.
Hercules and Aladdin meet in the crossover Hercules and the Arabian Knights.

Alan Partridge.description: Alan Partridge is a spin-off of The Day Today.
James Bond is mentioned often in Alan Partridge as Alan’s favourite series and in reference to Roger Moore.
One of Lawrence Knowles's nicknames is "King Kong".
One of Lawrence Knowles's nicknames is "Wolf Man".
One of Lawrence Knowles's nicknames is "Godzilla".

In Knowing Me Knowing You with Alan Partridge, Alan says if his show was a car it would be "Chatty Chatty Bang Bang". In I'm Alan Partridge, a listener on Alan's radio show named Sue says that she'd like to watch Chitty Chitty Bang Bang with Sting as part of a phone-in.
A character in Knowing Me Knowing You with Alan Partridge says Baywatch was his dad's favourite television show.
In Knowing Me Knowing You with Alan Partridge, Alan says "Yabba-dabba-doo", Fred Flintstone's catchphrase. Later on someone tells a joke starting "What does a Swedish Fred Flintstone say?"
In Knowing Me Knowing You with Alan Partridge, Two guests say how Tim Burton gave them the bat-mobile from this film and say "He directed Batman".

In Knowing Me Knowing Yule with Alan Partridge, Alan compares a wheelchair-bound guest to Daleks and Davros. In I'm Alan Partridge, When making robot jokes about Susan, Alan says "Tea or coffee?! Tea or coffee?!" in a Dalek voice. Also in another episode, Alan says that when he had mental health problems he bought the rights to K9, the robot dog.
In Knowing Me Knowing Yule with Alan Partridge, Alan mentions playing Mortal Kombat on his nephews video games console.
In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan refers to his wife Carol's lover as "Mr. Planet of the Apes Man."
In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan says that Hugh Morris, who has no vocal cords, sounds like the girl in The Exorcist.
In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan claims he was trying to access Driving Miss Daisy when being told about using an adult pay-channel in the hotel.
In I'm Alan Partridge, Making fun of Alan after the traffic cone incident, Dave Clifton asks him if he watched "Cone-an the Barbarian"
In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan compares Susan to R2-D2. In another episode, Alan walks while bending over and holding his ankles and says "I could have been R2-D2.
In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan shouts "Jurassic Park!" as an exclamation.
In I'm Alan Partridge, Raphael asks "Can I get to my car?" Alan responds "It's not going to drive off by itself, it's not Herbie."
In I'm Alan Partridge, a The Addams Family VHS is shown.
In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan uses "Mary Poppins" as an exclamation when he sees his friend's bike.
In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan talks about a helicopter and says "Like the beginning of Mash."
In I'm Alan Partridge, After Lynne gives Alan medical advice, he says "You're just quoting bits from Casualty now."

In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan claims his free torch is the same model as used on The X-Files. Also in another episode, after discovering he has various things in common with Dan, Alan says, "It's like The X Files, but a pleasant X Files."
In I'm Alan Partridge, During a bit of horseplay with Alan, Dan says "I'm the Terminator! You can't kill me!"
In I'm Alan Partridge, Alan refers to Tex as "the Duke of Hazzard."
In I'm Alan Partridge, A tax inspector says "Theres a receipt here for a cinema ticket for 1 for Shrek."
In the Little Britain episode, "Hard-Boiled Egg Eating", in the video rental shop, Alan Partridge's "Crash Bang Wallop! What a Video" can be seen on the shelf. This fictional video was made by Alan.
In Mid Morning Matters with Alan Partridge, Alan tries to book a ticket to see Inception at the cinema.
In Mid Morning Matters with Alan Partridge, Alan mentions Bill Oddie was one of the Goodies.
In Mid Morning Matters with Alan Partridge, Alan's SAS guest mentions wounded people looking like Muppet's mouths, and Sophie asks if the Muppet was hurt.
In Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa, Jason Treswell calls Lynn "Mrs. Doubtfire".
In Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa, The Godfather is referenced in dialogue as a great movie.
In Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa, an inept Alan Partridge escape attempt is dubbed "The Shitshank Redemption".
In Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa, The West Wing is mentioned when two characters are 'walking and talking.'
In Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa, Alan tells Lynn that Pat thinks he borrowed his phone to play Angry Birds on it.
In Mid Morning Matters with Alan Partridge, Simon calls Alan "Djangalan Unchained".
In This Time with Alan Partridge, Alan refers to the 'robot' from The Wizard of Oz.
In This Time with Alan Partridge, Ghost is mentioned.
In This Time with Alan Partridge, a Policeman talks about Fast and Furious in reference to Alan's driving.
Mrs Hobbs from Waffle the Wonder Dog appears in This Time with Alan Partridge episode 2.

Alan Wake.description: A book in Alan Wake features a picture of Alfred Wooden from Max Payne. Many other references to Max Payne can also be found in Alan Wake.

Albert Odyssey.description: The four main Hebereke characters make an appearance in Albert Odyssey.
A Lutecian (Roomi's race) appears in Albert Odyssey: Legend of Eldean as a shopkeeper.

Alchemia Story.description: Potum enemies from Toram Online appear in Alchemia Story as part of a special collaboration.

Alex Kidd.description: Altered Beast features tombstones with the names "Stella" and "Alex" on it, referencing Alex Kidd: The Lost Stars. Artwork of Altered Beast is featured in the Japanese instruction manual of Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle. One of the achievements from Alex Kidd in Miracle World DX is named after Altered Beast.
Artwork of Osomatsu-kun Hachamecha Gekijou is featured in the Japanese instruction manual of Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle.
Artwork of Space Harrier II is featured in the Japanese instruction manual of Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle.
The ending of Alex Kidd: High-Tech World features Alex Kidd playing OutRun.
Alex Kidd in Shinobi World is a crossover between the two series.

Alias.description: Pretty Woman is mentioned in the Alias episode "Truth Be Told".
Citizen Kane is mentioned in the Alias episode "Mea Culpa".
"You All Everybody", a song by the fictional band Drive Shaft from Lost, can be heard in the Alias episode "The Awful Truth".
WarGames is mentioned in the Alias episode "Out Of The Box".

Alice (CBS).description: Boss Hogg and Enos Strate from The Dukes of Hazzard appear in the Alice episode "Mel is Hogg-Tied".

Alice Comedies.description: Pegleg Pete, originally from Alice Comedies, appears as the main villain in the Oswald the Lucky Rabbit series, starting with the short The Ocean Hop.

Alice Fiction.description: Characters from Cytus II can be found in Alice Fiction as part of a collaboration event.
Hatsune Miku appears in Alice Fiction as a part of a collaboration event.
Characters from Crash Fever can be found in Alice Fiction as part of a collaboration event.
Characters from Re:Zero can be found in Alice Fiction as part of a collaboration event.

Alice Gear Aegis.description: Kasumi and Marie Rose appear in Alice Gear Aegis, while costumes from the game with functioning weapons appeared in Dead or Alive Xtreme Venus Vacation during special collaboration events.
Characters from Steins;Gate appear in Alice Gear Aegis as part of a special collaboration.

Alice Gear Aegis.game: The Saga of Tanya the Evil
Alice Gear Aegis.description: Tanya appears in Alice Gear Aegis as part of a special collaboration.

Alien (Fox).description: Alien is mentioned in Ferris Bueller's Day Off.
Alien vs. Predator is a comic crossover of both series which later expanded upon in games and films.
Superman crosses with Xenomorphs from Aliens.
Batman and Aliens had a comic book crossover together called Batman/Aliens.
Green Lantern Versus Aliens is a crossover series between Green Lantern and Alien.
Witchblade has a crossover with Alien in "Aliens/Predator/Witchblade/Darkness: Mindhunter Crossover".
Alien and Judge Dredd had a comic book crossover.
Prometheus is a spinoff of Alien.
Rick and Morty meet a Facehugger in a commercial for Alien: Covenant. In the Rick and Morty Pilot, during the Interdimensional Customs scene, a silhouette of a Xenomorph appears.
A crossover between Star Trek and Alien titled Acceptable Losses was planned, but later scrapped.

Alien Hominid.description: The Alien Hominid is mentioned in Pico's Cousin, and then appears in Pico's Cousin 2, while Alien Hominid vs. Pico is a crossover between the two series. There also are various references to Alien Hominid in the Pico Sim Date series.

Alien Nation.description: The characters of Alien Nation meet Planet of the Apes in "Ape Nation".
A Home Alone 6 poster is shown in Alien Nation: Dark Horizon.

All-Star Fighters.description: Aya and Riko appear as fighters in All-Star Fighters.
A Defense Force soldier appears as a fighter in All-Star Fighters.

All My Children.description: Several characters from All My Children and One Life to Live have crossed over into the other series.

Rae Cummings from General Hospital appeared in 9 episodes of All My Children and is the mother of Skye Chandler from All My Children; Skye Chandler became a major character on General Hospital; Anna Devane from General Hospital has made several appearances on All My Children and is the twin sister of Alex Marick from All My Children; Alex Marick has made several appearances on General Hospital; Mac Scorpio and Robin Scorpio-Drake from General Hospital have appeared on All My Children.

The two part Hot in Cleveland episode "I Love Lucci" makes several references to All My Children, and includes Victoria Chase getting a role on All My Children. Later, an episode of All My Children features a character played by Chase's actress Wendie Malick, though the role is credited to Victoria Chase, implying that this is the role her character gets in the Hot in Cleveland episode.

All in the Family.description: Maude is a spinoff of All In The Family.
The Jeffersons is a spinoff of All in the Family.

Alleyway.description: Mario is the pilot of the spaceship in Alleyway.

Ally McBeal.description: Judge Jennifer (Whipper) Cone appears on the Practice episode "Line of Duty". Also, most of the primary Practice cast members guest starred in the Ally McBeal episode "The Inmates".

Alphas.description: Dr. Vanessa Calder, a recurring character on Warehouse 13, appears in the Alphas episode "Never Let Me Go".

Alpine Racer.description: A billboard of a christmas-themed Pac-Man can be seen in the Intermediate Course in Alpine Racer.
A billboard of a christmas-themed Valkyrie can be seen in the Intermediate Course in Alpine Racer.
Kuma from Tekken is a secret character in Alpine Racer 2.
Don from Point Blank is a secret character in Alpine Racer 2.
Klonoa is a secret character in Alpine Racer 3.

Altered Beast.description: Altered Beast features tombstones with the names "Stella" and "Alex" on it, referencing Alex Kidd: The Lost Stars.Artwork of Altered Beast is featured in the Japanese instruction manual of Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle. One of the achievements from Alex Kidd in Miracle World DX is named after Altered Beast.

Amagami.description: Amagami Tetris is part of both series.

Amazing Stories.description: The Hulk appears in the Amazing Stories episode "Remote Control Man".
Arnold Jackson appears in the Amazing Stories episode "Remote Control Man".
Face appears in the Amazing Stories episode "Remote Control Man".
June Cleaver appears in the Amazing Stories episode "Remote Control Man".
K.I.T.T. appears in the Amazing Stories episode "Remote Control Man".
Aunt Esther Anderson appears in the Amazing Stories episode "Remote Control Man".

American Dad.description: Roger Smith says he does not have an 'ET finger thing' in the American Dad episode "Pilot".
24 is mentioned in the American Dad! episode "Threat Levels".

Roger appears in the Family Guy episodes Meet the Quagmires, The Simpsons Guy, Blue Harvest, It's A Trap! and Send in Stewie, Please. Barney appears in the Family Guy episode Killer Queen. Stan and Avery appear in the Family Guy episode Lois Kills Stewie while Stan makes a cameo in the episode Excellence in Broadcasting. Brian makes a cameo in the American Dad episode The People vs. Martin Sugar while he and Stewie make a cameo in the American Dad episode The Worst Stan.  Peter appears in the American Dad episode Hurricane!.

Ryu from Street Fighter appears as a character in the browser game American Dad vs. Family Guy Kung-Fu II; Akiko appears dressed as Chun-Li in the American Dad! episode "Best Little Horror House in Langley Falls".
Breakfast Club is shown in a drive in theater in the American Dad episode "Failure Is Not A Factory Installed Option".
Sixth Sense is mentioned in the American Dad episode "When A Stan Loves A Woman".
Keyser Soze is mentioned in the American Dad episode "When A Stan Loves A Woman".
Unbreakable is mentioned in the American Dad episode "When A Stan Loves A Woman".
Jerry Maguire is mentioned in the American Dad episode "I Can't Stan You".
Roger wears a Predator costume in the American Dad episode "Joint Custody".

A character based on Mario can be seen in the American Dad! episode "A Piñata Named Desire", while in "School Lies" a parody of Donkey Kong can be seen; there also are other references to the game in other episodes.
The Cleveland Show has a crossover with American Dad! in Hurricane!.
Jeff named a orphan Nemo after the film "Finding Nemo".
Characters from Small Soldiers appear in the American Dad! episode: "Toy Whorey".
When Harry Met Sally... is mentioned in the American Dad episode: "Poltergasm".
Steve plays with Pokémon Trading Cards in Buck, Wild.
Mister Bean is mentioned in the American Dad! episode "News Glance With Genevieve Vavance".
Stan mentions the Care Bears: Big Wish movie in the episode Dreaming of a White Porsche Christmas.
Groundhog Day is mentioned in the American Dad episode "Father's Daze".
The Season 13 episode "Paranoid Frandroid" of American Dad! features an Arcade machine called "Bubble Trouble", a spoof of Buble Bobble.
Blue Bloods is mentioned in the American Dad episode "Wild Women Do".
Characters play Overwatch in the American Dad episode "Brave N00b World".
The Boss Baby is referenced in the Season 15 episode "Exquisite Corpses" of American Dad!.
In the episode Henderson, Klaus’ fishbowl is decorated for his date with Danuta, with two of the decorations being Pickle Rick.

American Dragon: Jake Long.description: Ingrid Third appears in American Dragon: Jake Long in the background of the episode The Halloween Bash.
The cheerleader outfits worn in Kim Possible are seen in the American Dragon: Jake Long episode The Halloween Bash.

American McGee's Alice.description: Raz's skeleton appears in Alice: Madness Returns.

American Psycho.description: The Grinch is mentioned in American Psycho.
The Texas Chainsaw Massacre appears on a TV in American Psycho.

Amiibo Tap.description: Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Balloon Fight.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Clu Clu Land.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Donkey Kong or Donkey Kong Jr..
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Excitebike.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of F-Zero.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Ice Climber.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Kid Icarus.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Kirby's Adventure, Kirby Super Star, Kirby's Dream Land 3, or Kirby's Dream Course.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Mach Rider.

Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Dr. Mario, Super Mario Bros., Super Mario Bros.: The Lost Levels, Super Mario Bros. 2, Super Mario Bros 3., Super Mario Kart or Super Mario World.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Metroid or Super Metroid.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Pinball.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Punch-Out!!.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Wario's Woods.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Wrecking Crew.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of Yoshi.
Scanning an Amiibo in Amiibo Tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits can give you access to playing a demo of The Legend of Zelda, Zelda II: The Adventure of Link, or The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past.

Among Us.description: The diamond and teleporter from Henry Stickmin can be found in Among Us, there's a poster for The Henry Stickmin Collection in the MIRA HQ map, Henry and Ellie Rose appear as selectable pets and several cosmetics are taken from Henry Stickmin characters; the Henry Stickmin Collection includes sound effects from Among Us and plushies as collectables, a reference to its expelled screen and minor nods; a later update to Among Us adds a map based on the Airship from Infiltrating the Airship.
The energy sword from Halo appears in the Airship map in Among Us.
Ratchet costume and Clank pet are available for the PS4 and PS5 versions of Among Us.
Cosmetics based on League of Legends appeared in Among Us as part of a special collaboration.
Ghostface is playable available in Among Us as a part of the Scream collab.
Many cosmetics based on members of Hololive appear in Among Us as part of a special collaboration.
Benoit Blanc plays Among Us in Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery. A costume based on Benoit Blanc is available in Among Us

In an update, stickers based on Among Us can be obtained if both Among Us and A Hat in Time are owned on Steam. Additionally, accessories for Hat Kid, Bow Kid, Mustache Girl and the Conductor as well as a Crow pet can be obtained as part of the Indie Cosmicube event in Among Us.
Accessories for the Alien Hominid can be obtained as part of the Indie Cosmicube event in Among Us.
Accessories for Hatty Hattington can be obtained as part of the Indie Cosmicube event in Among Us.
Accessories for the Crashers and Kingley as well as a Rammy pet can be obtained as part of the Indie Cosmicube event in Among Us.
Accessories for the Madeline, Badeline, Theo and the Bird as well as a Flying Strawberry pet can be obtained as part of the Indie Cosmicube event in Among Us.
Accessories for the Cadence, Nocturna and Frederick as well as a Bone Shaker pet can be obtained as part of the Indie Cosmicube event in Among Us.
Accessories for the Sans, Papyrus, Undyne and Flowey as well as a Napstamate pet can be obtained as part of the Indie Cosmicube event in Among Us.
Accessories for the the Gardener, the Wimp and the Goose as well as a Goose pet can be obtained as part of the Indie Cosmicube event in Among Us.

Amphibia.description: There’s a doll of Cricket from Big City Green in the Amphibia episode “A Night at the Inn”, while a doll of Sprig from Amphibia can be seen in the Big City Greens episode "Present Tense".

There are frogs in Amphibia that resemble Stan and Soos from Gravity Falls.  Frog Soos also mentions the concept of multiple parallel universes. In the Amphibia episode "True Colors", an illustration of Bill Cipher can be seen in a book read by Marcy. Additionally, a Gideon Gleeful plush toy is seen in the background of Amphibia's opening during season 3.
Master Roshi appears in the Amphibia episode "Hollywood Hop Pop".

Am\u00e9lie.description: In Amélie, Amélie Poulain dresses up as Zorro.

An American Werewolf.description: The Muppets is shown on TV in An American Werewolf in London.
Toys of Mickey and Minnie Mouse appear in An American Werewolf in London.
A toy of Donnald Duck appears in An American Werewolf in London.

Anarchy Reigns.description: Characters from MadWorld appear in Anarchy Reigns. Anarchy Reigns serves as a spiritual successor to MadWorld.
Bayonetta is DLC for Anarchy Reigns.

Anchorman.description: A book of Garfield comics can be seen in Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues.

Angel (Warner Bros.).description: Angel is a spinoff series of Buffy the Vampire Slayer.
Blair Witch is mentioned in the Angel episode "Through The Looking Glass".
Pretty Woman is mentioned in the Angel episode "Carpe Noctem".
Skip mentions he hates Russle Crowe's Gladiator in the Angel episode "Birthday".
In "Harm's Way", Weyland-Yutani is mentioned as a client of Wolfram and Hart.
In the Angel episode "You're Welcome", Spike plays a game implied to be Donkey Kong.

Angry Beavers.description: In the Angry Beavers episode "Dumbwaiters" when Dag and Norb open up the box full of rubber masks one of them is Helga Pataki from Hey Arnold!
Daggett and Norbert from The Angry Beavers were originally gonna make a cameo in the episode "Schooled!" during the song "Welcome to Canada" but they were cut for unknown reasons.

Angry Birds.description: In the "Short Fuse" chapter from Angry Birds there is a pig dressed as Walter White.
One of Chuck's Bird Wear costumes in Angry Birds Seasons is Pikachu.
One of Bomb's Bird Wear costumes in Angry Birds Seasons is RoboCop.
One of Bomb's Bird Wear costumes in Angry Birds Seasons is Rudolph.
Matilda has a ninja turtle costume in Angry Birds Seasons.
One of Bubbles' Bird Wear costumes in Angry Birds Seasons is Bruce Banner.
Angry Birds Rio is a crossover between both series'.
Angry Birds Cheetos is a format crossover between the two series; Chester Cheetah appears in Angry Birds Vuela Tazos.
Angry Birds Star Wars and Angry Birds Star Wars II are crossovers between both series'.

As part of a collaboration event, Puzzle & Dragons featured a dungeon with creatures from Angry Birds; in a second collab event, Puzzle & Dragons featured creatures from Angry Birds Epic and vice versa.
Quicky appears in Angry Birds Breakfast.
Popeye appears in the subscription of Angry Birds Issue 2. Popeye later appears again in Angry Birds Friends.
Angry Birds Transformers is a crossover between both series'. There are also comic crossovers.
Angry Birds characters meet Froot Loops characters in an Angry Birds Space update.
The episode "Dois bicudos" is a crossover between Angry Birds: The Movie and Monica Toy.
One of Matilda's Bird Wear costumes in Angry Birds Seasons is Jason.
One of Stella's Bird Wear costumes in Angry Birds Seasons is Catwoman.
The Baby Shark song is danced to in The Angry Birds Movie 2.
An officially licensed figure was released by Youtooz called "Angry Berd" that showed one of the Berd characters with the appearance of Bomb from Angry Birds.
Smurfs characters appear in Angry Birds Friends during a special collaboration.
In Angry Birds Epic!, the Squared Forest and the Squarewood item is a reference to the game. An Angry Birds DLC was added to Minecraft.
The Angry Birds and Sonic the Hedgehog series have several collaborations with each other.

Angry Video Game Nerd.description: The first episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Castlevania II: Simon's Quest; he then reviews many games from the series in the four-part "Castlevania" episode; he also reviews the unofficial game Castlevania II: Simon's Quest - Redaction in the eposode "Desert Bus".
The third episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES game The Karate Kid.
The fourth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES game Who Framed Roger Rabbit and he also plays it in the episode "Back to the Future Re-Revisited".

The fifth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES game Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, while the eighteenth and nineteenth are a review of the movie Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles III; he then completes the review of the NES game in the episode "Back to the Future Re-revisited".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews various Back to the Future games in the episodes "Back to the Future" and "Back to the Future Re-revisited".
The seventh episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of M.C. Kids.
The eighth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Wally Bear and the NO! Gang.
The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "Top Gun" is a review of two Top Gun games; he also plays the NES Top Gun in the episodes "The Power Glove", "NES Accessories" and "Back to the Future Re-Revisited".
The eleventh episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Double Dragon III.

The Angry Video Game Nerd plays Super Mario Bros. in the video "The Anger Begins" and references the series in many episodes of the series, then reviews Mario's Tennis, Mario Clash, Super Mario Bros. 3, Hotel Mario, Mario is Missing, Mario's Time Machine and Mario Paint in various episodes of the series.
The twelfth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES game Friday the 13th.
The thirteenth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES game Nightmare on Elm Street.
The sixteenth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the Sega Master System game Rocky; he also reviews Rocky Super Action Boxing in the episode "Double Vision: Part 2".
UNDIRECT: The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the NES game DuckTales in an episode of ScrewAttack's Video Game Vault.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews various Ghostbusters games in the twenty-first, twenty-second and twenty-third episodes of the series.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews various Spider-Man games in the twenty-fourth episode of the series and Spider-Man and Venom: Maximum Carnage in the episode "Wish List (Part 2)".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Time Gal in the episode "Sega CD".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews The Adventures of Willy Beamish in the episode "Sega CD".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Primal Rage in the episode "Sega 32X".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Sega 32X version of Doom in the episode "Sega 32X" and the Jaguar version in the episode "Atari Jaguar Part 2".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Virtua Fighter in the episode "Sega 32X".
The twenty-seventh episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES game Silver Surfer.
The twenty-eighth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES game Die Hard.
The twenty-nineth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the PlayStation game Independence Day.
The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "The Simpsons" is a review of two Simpsons games.
The thirty-first episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Bugs Bunny's Birthday Blowout; he also reviews the Bugs Bunny Crazy Castle games in the seventy-fifth episode of the series.
The Angry Video Game Nerd talks about Fester's Quest in the episode "Nintendo Power", and reviews it along the Genesis game The Addams Family in the next episode.
The thirty-fifth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the Atari game Texas Chainsaw Massacre.
The Angry Video Game Nerd finds the Atari game Halloween in the episode "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and reviews it in the following episode.

The Angry Video Game Nerd shows briefly the Atari game E.T. in the episodes "Halloween" and "Spielberg Games", then mentions it in the episode "Schwarzenegger Games"; the plot of The Angry Video Game Nerd: The Movie is centered around the E.T. game and he also reviews it in the 120th episode of the series.
The thirty-seventh episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES version of Dragon's Lair.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the NES game Home Alone 2 in the episode "An Angry Nerd Christmas Carol: Part 1".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Far Cry Vengeance in the episode "An Angry Nerd Christmas Carol: Part 2".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Super Monkey Ball: Banana Blitz in the episode "An Angry Nerd Christmas Carol: Part 2".

The Angry Video Game Nerd talks about the Zelda series in the episode "Chronologically Confused About the Legend of Zelda Timeline" and reviews the three CD-i Zelda games and Zelda II in later episodes.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews some Rambo games in the episode "Rambo".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Galactic Pinball in the episode "Virtual Boy".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Teleroboxer in the episode "Virtual Boy".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Virtual Boy Wario Land in the episode "Virtual Boy".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Panic Bomber in the episode "Virtual Boy".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Nester's Funky Bowling in the episode "Virtual Boy".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews 3D Tetris in the episode "Virtual Boy".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Virtual Boy game Waterworld in the episode "Virtual Boy".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Jack Bros. in the episode "Virtual Boy".
The fourty-third episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the SNES game The Wizard of Oz.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Masters of the Universe: The Power of He-Man in the episode "Double Vision: Part 1".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Tron: Deadly Discs in the episode "Double Vision: Part 1".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Intellivision game Advanced Dungeons & Dragons in the episode "Double Vision: Part 1".

The Nostalgia Critic talks about the Angry Video Game Nerd in his '"Nerd Rant" videos, and the Nerd responds in his "AVGN responds to the Nostalgia Critic!" video, starting a feud that concludes in a crossover fight; later they review together Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Making of the Coming Out of Their Shells Tour and the 2014 movie Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews The Wizard in the episode "The Wizard and Super Mario Bros. 3".
The Angry Video Game Nerd plays Duck Hunt in the episode "NES Accessories".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Super Scope in the episode "NES Accessories" and a weapon based on it also appear in Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures.
The Angry Video Game Nerd plays the NES game Beetlejuice in the episode "NES Accessories" and later in The 121st episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Beetlejuice for the NES.
R.O.B. makes an appearance in The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "NES Accessories" and the Nerd reviews it in the episode "R.O.B. the Robot".
The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "Indiana Jones" is a review of some Indiana Jones games.
The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "Star Trek" is a review of some Star Trek games.
The Angry Video Game Nerd episodes "Superman" and "Superman 64" are reviews of some Superman games.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews various Batman games in the fifty-second and fifty-third episodes of the series, and also plays some Batman games in the episode "Tiger Electronic Games".
The fifty-fifth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES version of Battletoads.
The fifty-sixth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES game Dick Tracy.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Sesame Street: Countdown in the episode "Dracula" and Elmo's Number Journey in the Special Message for donating to the movie foundraising on indiegogo.com.
The sixty-third episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the Genesis game Michael Jackson's Moonwalker.
The sixty-fourth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Milon's Secret Castle.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Tempest 2000 in the episode "Atari Jaguar Part 2".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Jaguar game Alien vs. Predator in the episode "Atari Jaguar Part 2" and the NES game Alien 3 in the episode "Alien 3".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Jaguar game Alien vs. Predator in the episode "Atari Jaguar Part 2" and reviews the NES game Predator in the episode "Schwarzenegger Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews many Terminator games in the episodes "The Terminator" and "Terminator 2", and also briefly in the episode "Schwarzenegger Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews various X-Men games in the 69th episode of the series, and the HyperScan game X-Men in episode 131.
The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "Transformers" is a review of two Transformers games.
The Angry Video Game Nerd shows the NES game Barbie in the episode "Bugs Bunny's Crazy Castle", then reviews it in the episode "The Making of an Angry Video Game Nerd Episode".
The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "Bugs Bunny's Crazy Castle" is a review of the Crazy Castle series.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Woody Woodpecker in Crazy Castle 5 in the episode "Bugs Bunny's Crazy Castle".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews various Godzilla games in the seventy-seventh episode of the series.
The seventy-eighth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES and SNES games based on Wayne's World.

The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Street Fighter 2010, Fighting Street and Street Fighter: The Movie in the episode "Street Fighter 2010"; he also talks about the Tiger LCD version of Street Fighter II in the episode "Tiger Electronic Games".
The eighty-seventh episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Ninja Gaiden.
The eighty-ninth episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of various "Pong" consoles.
The Angry Video Game Nerd plays GTA IV in the episode "Pong Consoles".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Golgo 13: Top Secret Episode during Pat the NES Punk's first NES Marathon.
The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "How The Nerd Stole Christmas" features a reference to Kirby.

The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "How The Nerd Stole Christmas" features a reference to Mega Man; the Nerd then reviews the Tiger LCD version of Mega Man 2 in the episode "Tiger Electronic Games", the cover art of Mega Man in AVGN: Bad Game Cover Art #2 and many games from the Mega Man series in Episode 139.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Circus Caper in the episode "How The Nerd Stole Christmas".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the NES game Fist of the North Star in the episode "How The Nerd Stole Christmas".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews many Star Wars games in the episode "Star Wars".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the NES game Jaws in the episode "Spielberg Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the NES game Hook in the episode "Spielberg Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews some Jurassic Park games in the episode "Spielberg Games" and the Game.com The Lost World game in "Tiger Electronic Games".

The Angry Video Game Nerd is mentioned in DEATH BATTLE! vs The World. Wiz and Boomstick from Death Battle! make an appearance in Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures. Scenes from The Angry Video Game Nerd Adventures 2: ASSimilation is shown in Ratchet & Clank VS Jak & Daxter.
The 104th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Nintendo World Championships.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews River City Ransom during Pat the NES Punk's 2nd NES Marathon.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the NES game Last Action Hero in the episode "Shwarzenegger Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd plays Commando in the episode "Schwarzenegger Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Bubble Bobble during Pat the NES Punk's 3rd NES Marathon.
The 108th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES version of Ghosts 'N Goblins.
The 110th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES version of Ikari Warriors.
The 111th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the Toxic Crusaders video game.
The 112th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Bill & Ted's Excellent Video Game Adventure.
The Angry Video Game Nerd plays the Tiger LCD game Dinosaurs in the episode "Tiger Electronic Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Tiger LCD game Full House in the episode "Tiger Electronic Games".

The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Game.Com version of Mortal Kombat Trilogy in the episode "Tiger Electronic Games"; while episode 138 of the show is a review of the Nintendo 64 version of Mortal Kombat Mythologies: Sub-Zero.
The Angry Video Game Nerd plays the Game.Com version of Duke Nukem 3D in the episode "Tiger Electronic Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd plays the Game.Com version of Resident Evil 2 in the episode "Tiger Electronic Games".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Sky Kid during Pat the NES Punk's 4th NES Marathon.
Board James makes an appearance in The Angry Video Game Nerd episodes "AVGN Games!" and "The Crow", while the Nerd appears in the Board James episode "Video Games !!"
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Bad Dudes Vs. DragonNinja in the episode "Wish List (Part 1)".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Karate Champ in the episode "Wish List (Part 1)".

The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Sonic Blast, Sonic Labyrinth, Sonic R and Sonic Shuffle in the episode "Wish List (Part 1)", while Episode 145 of the show is a review of the 2006 game Sonic the Hedgehog.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Shadow the Hedgehog in the episode "Wish List (Part 1)".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the NES game Where's Waldo? in the episode "Wish List (Part 1)".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews A Boy and His Blob: Trouble on Blobolonia in the episode "Wish List (Part 2)".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the NES game The Three Stooges in the episode "Wish List (Part 2)".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the SNES game Home Improvement in the episode "Wish List (Part 2)".
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Bubsy 3D in the episode "Wish List (Part 2)".
The Nerd reviews The Adventures of Bayou Billy in the "Bayou Billy/Punisher" double review with Pat the NES Punk.
The NES game The Punisher is reviewed by Pat the NES Punk in the "Bayou Billy/Punisher" double review with the Nerd.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Adventure Island during Pat the NES Punk's 5th NES Marathon.
The 123rd episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the Sega Master System game ALF.
The 125th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Ren & Stimpy: Fire Dogs.
The 126th episode of "The Angry Video Game Nerd" is a review of "Rocky & Bullwinkle" for the NES.
The 129th episode of "The Angry Video Game Nerd" is a review of the NES game Lethal Weapon.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the HyperScan game Ben 10 in the 131st episode of the show.
The 132nd episode of "The Angry Video Game Nerd" is a review of Universal Studios Theme Parks Adventure.
The 134th episode of "The Angry Video Game Nerd" is a review of the Super Famicom game Hong Kong 97.
The 135th episode of "The Angry Video Game Nerd" is a review of the TurboGrafx-16 game Darkwing Duck.
The 137th episode of "The Angry Video Game Nerd" is a review of the Sega Saturn game The Crow: City of Angels.
A poster for Donkey Kong Country 2 can be seen in Angry Video Game Nerd II: ASSimilation.
The 140th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the NES version of Paperboy.
The 141st episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of the game Beavis and Butt-Head for Genesis and SNES.
The 142nd episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of a few Berenstain Bears games.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews The Adventures of Gilligan's Island during Pat the NES Punk's 7th NES Marathon.
The 144th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of various Power Rangers and Super Sentai games.
The 146th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Planet of the Apes for PlayStation.
The Nerd reviews the Game Boy Camera in episode 147.
The 151st episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews NES RoboCop games.
The 153rd episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Charlie’s Angels for GameCube.
The 156th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Earthbound for SNES.
The 157th episode ofThe Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Dirty Harry for NES.
The 159th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews a few Tomb Raider games.
The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews the Amiga CD32 game Zool in the 162nd episode of the show.
The Angry Video Game Nerd talks about the Kingdom Hearts series in the episode "Kingdom Hearts Timeline - Chronologically Confused".
The 167th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Pepsi Man for the PlayStation.
The 171st episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Chex Quest for the PC.
The 174th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Spawn games.
The 179th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Dennis the Menace for the SNES.
The 181st episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Final Fight games.
The 182nd episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Mission: Impossible for the N64.
The 183rd episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Ecco the Dolphin for the Sega Genesis.
The 185th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews The Legend of Kage for the NES.
The 186th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Taito Legends and Taito Legends 2.
The 188th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Shrek: Fairy Tale Freakdown for the Game Boy Color.
The 189th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Darkman for the NES.
The 191st episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Gex for the 3DO.
The 191st episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Alone in the Dark and Alone in the Dark 2 for the 3DO.
The 195th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews Pac-Man 2: The New Adventures for the Sega Genesis.
The 196th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd reviews The Rocketeer for the NES and SNES.
The Angry Video Game Nerd episode "Garfield" is a review of three Garfield games.
The 207th episode of The Angry Video Game Nerd is a review of Kid Icarus.

Ani-Mayhem.description: Ranma ½ cards are featured in Ani-Mayhem.
A Dragon Ball Z set is released for Ani-Mayhem.

Animal Crossing.description: Balloon Fight is featured as an unlockable playable game in Animal Forest and its revisions.
Clu Clu Land is featured as an unlockable playable game in Animal Forest, with Clu Clu Land D added in its revisions.
Golf is featured as an unlockable playable game in Animal Forest and its revisions.
Pinball is featured as an unlockable playable game in Animal Forest and its revisions.
Tennis is featured as an unlockable playable game in Animal Forest and its revisions.

Rupees from the Zelda series appear in Animal Forest and later games in the series, while Wolf Link, Medli, Ganon and Epona appear in Animal Crossing: New Leaf when scanning Zelda amiibo. Hyrule is also mentioned in various Animal Crossing games while Linebeck is mentioned in New Horizons and there are other minor references as well.
An Arwing from the Star Fox series appears as an item in all Animal Crossing games.

Animal Forest and its sequels mention locations from the Mario series; the downloadable content pack Animal Crossing × Mario Kart 8 for Mario Kart 8 includes elements from the Animal Crossing series; there also are Mario-themed clothes and furnitures in the series as well as other minor references.
Animal Forest and its revisions mention a location from Golden Sun.

The Pokémon Pikachu console makes an appearance in Animal Forest and its sequels; one of the designs in the Animal Crossing e-Reader cards is based on the Pokéball; various Pokémon-themed items appeared in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp during a special event.
Baseball is featured as an unlockable playable game in Dobutsu no Mori+ and its revisions.
Ice Climber is featured in Dobutsu no Mori+ through special means and in Animal Crossing by scanning the respective e-reader card.
ExciteBike is featured as an unlockable playable game in Animal Crossing.
Soccer is featured as an unlockable playable game in Animal Crossing.
Elements from the Metroid series appear in many Animal Crossing games as clothes and furnitures.
Puppet versions of Nintendogs are featured in Animal Crossing: City Folk.
The Blue Falcon from F-Zero appears as a forniture item in Animal Crossing: City Folk and New Leaf.

Captain Olimar sends a letter to the player during a special event in the PAL version of Animal Crossing: City Folk. Additionally Animal Crossing games feature items based on the Pikmin series, while scanning Animal Crossing amiibo in Hey! Pikmin, makes the figures appear in the game.

In a DLC for the European version of Animal Crossing: City Folk, Little Mac sends a letter and a gift to the player's character; Punch-Out!! Featuring Mr. Dream is also featured as an unlockable playable game in Dobutsu no Mori+ and its revisions.
Animal Crossing: New Leaf features a reference to the Mother series.
Animal Crossing: New Leaf features a shrine based on Totoro.

A Felyne appears in Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer by scanning a Monster Hunter Stories amiibo; additionally Monster Hunter 4G/Ultimate features downloadable outfits based on Isabelle and Mister Resetti from the Animal Crossing series.
Animal Crossing: New Leaf includes the minigame Animal Forest Panepon/Animal Crossing Puzzle League as well as Lip's clothes and wand, added with the Welcome amiibo update.
Scanning a Hello Kitty amiibo card in Animal Crossing: New Leaf and New Horizons unlocks Hello Kitty themed furniture.
Scanning a Cinnamoroll amiibo card in Animal Crossing: New Leaf unlocks Cinnamoroll themed furniture.
Splatoon squids can be collected in an event in Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp; Animal Crossing: New Leaf also features Splatoon-themed items and furniture.
Crocodile Isle from Donkey Kong Country 2 is mentioned in Animal Crossing: New Horizons; there also are other minor references between the two series.

Captain Syrup from the Wario Land series is mentioned by Gullivarrr in Animal Crossing: New Horizons (added with update 1.3.0), while Wario characters directly interact with the "Animal Crossing: New Leaf" microgame in WarioWare: Get It Together!; there also are other minor references between the two series.

Animaniacs.description: Bonkers is occasionally mentioned in Animaniacs.
Belle and the Beast appear in the episode "King Yakko".
Yakko sings "Citizen Kane-y" and holds up a sled with "Rosebud" written on it in the Animaniacs episode "Garage Sale Of The Century".
Batman and Robin appear in an episode of Animaniacs.
Babs and Buster Bunny make an appearance in an episode of Animaniacs.
Edward Scissorhands is spoofed in the Animaniacs episode "Skullhead Boneyhands"; Edward Scissorhands comes alive in his video case cover in the Animaniacs episode "Video Review".
A Boyz N The Hood video case appears for a brief moment in the Animaniacs episode "Video Review".
Leonard Part 6 is among the featured titles in the Animaniacs episode "Video Review".
Characters from Looney Tunes appear in Animaniacs.

Freakazoid appears in the Animaniacs episodes "This Pun for Hire" and "The Big Wrap Party Tonight", and is seen on the cover of a magazine in "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Clock". Wakko from Animaniacs appears in the Freakazoid! episode "The Freakazoid".
The show, Pinky and the Brain is a spinoff of Animaniacs.

Dot mentioned The Simpsons in the Animaniacs episode "Hooray for North Hollywood" and Bart makes a cameo in the episode. In The Simpsons episode "Krusty the Clown", the Animaniacs reboot was seen as one of the many tv shows that appeared on screen.
Yakko, Wakko, and Dot sing a song about Captain Planet in a Kids' WB promo.
Johnny Bravo appears in a promo for Animaniacs.
A tour guide mentions a fountain for the Friends opening in the Animaniacs sketch, “Good Warner Hunting”.

Anime Abandon.description: Bennett The Sage reviews “Akira”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “The Fatal Fury Motion Picture”.
Bennet The Sage reviews “Sonic the Hedgehog: The Movie”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Neon Genesis Evangelion: Death and Rebirth” and “The End of Evangelion”.
The Nostalgia Critic's appears on Bennett’s review of "Guyver".
Bennett The Sage reviews "Guyver".
Bennett The Sage reviews “City Hunter”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Yu Yu Hakusho: The Poltergeist Report”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Street Fighter II The Animated Movie”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Inuyasha”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Speed Racer (AA)”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “FLCL”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Ghost in the Shell: Solid State Society” and sequels later on.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Pokémon: The Movie”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “The Digimon Movie”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Dragon Ball Z: The World's Strongest”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Sailor Moon R: The Movie”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Berserk”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Mobile Suit Gundam F91”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Jojo's Bizarre Adventure”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Teen Titans: Trouble in Tokyo”.
Bennett The Sage reviews “Hellsing”.
Bennett The Sage reviews the 1994 movie “Samurai Shodown”.

Anime Weebs.description: The weeb from Anime Weebs first appears in the Console Wars episode "End of Xbox One?".

Animorphs.description: The Animorphs toyline was released under the Transformers brand name. According to Ask Vector Prime, the two series exist in the same Megaverse.

Annalynn.description: Dynamite Anton is a playable character in the Nintendo Switch port of Annalynn.

Annie.description: The Starship Enterprise  was mentioned in the 2014 Annie movie.
Jimmy Neutron was mentioned in the 2014 Annie movie.
Ariel is seen in the Annie 2014 movie.

Anno Dracula.description: Geneviève Dieudonne, a character from several Warhammer novels, also appears in Anno Dracula.

Annoying Orange.description: Annoying Orange Super Mario is a parody of Mario and characters play Mario games in later episodes.
Pacmania is a parody of Pacman. Ms. Pac-Man is mentioned in Grapefruit's Revenge and characters play Pacman games in later episodes.

The Annoying Orange appears in Fred Goes Grocery Shopping feat. Annoying Orange while on that same day FЯED appears in Annoying Orange - Annoying Orange vs. FRED!!!. FЯED also appears in many episodes of Ask Orange.
Godzilla is mentioned in Orange of July, while Gourdzilla is a parody of Godzilla and characters watch a trailer of Godzilla King Of The Monsters in Trailer Trashed.
Pear watches Twilight in The Sitcom.

Charlie the Drunk Guinea Pig from Smosh is in the episode Annoying Saw 2: The Annoying Death Trap; The Annoying Orange appears in HARRY POTTER DELETED SCENES!, and makes a cameo in I LOST MY HAIR!. Smosh is mentioned in Ned Meets The Annoying Orange; Orange said that he is a fan of Smosh in U Can't Squash This, and Ian and Anthony made a cameo in the episode. Annoying Orange characters watch a trailer of Smosh: The Movie in Trailer Trashed.
Annoying Orange vs Angry Birds is a parody of Angry Birds and characters play Angry Birds games in later episodes.
Annoying Orange vs Mortal Kombat is a parody of Mortal Kombat and characters play Mortal Kombat games in later episodes.
